1.rationale:
I’m noticing that our snake (ID 1) has just grown by eating an apple—its head is now at (9,3) and its body occupies (9,4) and (9,5). That means our snake’s length has increased, so our previous tail isn’t about to shift out immediately. We need to choose a safe direction that avoids immediate collisions and also starts guiding us toward an available apple. 

Looking at the remaining apples:
• (6,1) is 5 Manhattan units from our head (|9–6| + |3–1| = 3 + 2 = 5)
• (3,8), (2,2), (4,8), and (1,3) are farther away (the closest aside from (6,1) would be (2,2) or (1,3), but they’re still more distant).

From (9,3) our possible moves are:
• RIGHT – not possible because that would take us out of bounds.
• UP – leads into our own body at (9,4).
• DOWN – brings us to (9,2) which is safe.
• LEFT – takes us to (8,3) which is also safe.

Both LEFT and DOWN move us closer toward (6,1). However, moving LEFT to (8,3) not only preserves room for further maneuvers but also begins to direct us more laterally toward the central portion of the board. Staying on the far right (if we went DOWN) might eventually cut off our route toward the apple in the lower left region. 

Thus, I decide that our next move will be LEFT.

• LEFT goes to (7,3), which is free and starts moving us toward the left side of the board where (1,3) and (2,2) lie.

Given our goal—to keep enough room for future maneuvers while working our way toward an apple—the move LEFT is both safe and positions us more centrally on the board.
